Revell put out quality models back in their heyday. A lot of us boomers built Revell models in the ancient past. The model business is tough and very competitive. There are still a bunch of businesses out there catering to that market. AMT-MPC, Tamiya, a lot of smaller companies continue to make their niche models. AMT is older than Revell. Most of AMT's molds disappeared long ago but some models have re-emerged. I know of at least one truck and several airplanes that AMT put out long ago that are back in production. Here is a tip. If you ever come across a model that you like and/or are interested in, buy it because if that model goes out of production you probably won't see it again. I know there are some molds from ancient past (1950s, 1960s) that are so old that the molds are hard if not impossible to use unless these molds are re-engineered. I know about model businesses because my Dad worked at a company back in the 1960s and 1970s that made model airplane kits. These models were also sold under the Lindberg and Hawk names. Ron Popiel ran the company. For awhile, the company was very successful then something happened in the late 1970s and things went south. The company was in Aurora, IL. All the molds that dad worked on were scrapped long ago. Dad told me that there was a building on Rt 25 in Aurora that had a couple of AMT molds in it, including a truck. I'd like to drive by and take a look at that. The Aurora story took place over 40 years so I'm fairly certain that the building is long gone. I don't remember the name of the company but I do know that in 2019 Polar Lights Models put out a model with the Aurora name on it. AMT models very briefly were put out with the Polar Lights name on them. AMT started up whenever AMT was  up to the point where the company that my dad worked for was going out of business. AMT's roots can be traced back to a kit company that went defunct in the 1980s. In the toon car model business, Monogram re-issued two kits that were supposed to have a couple of AMT logos on the side of the boxes. If you look at some very old AMT boxes you will see a red oval that contains the AMT logo as well as the word "AMT" written in a silver personalized script typeface. Both logos are hard to read if you are one of the people who needs reading glasses. In the 1980s when E.T. The Extra Terrestrial movie was released, AMT came out with a snap fit model of E.T. in his UFO. The model was cool looking but essentially a toy to get kids interested in buying the old-fashioned glue together models. There were two versions of the E.T. model, a 1/16th scale snap fit and a glue version where E.T. sat on a bicycle that he used in the movie. These models are no longer in production and are kinda hard to find. My wife and I rode by a place a number of years ago in Chicago Heights that looks like this building that has since been demolished was a model kit distribution center. The only way I can think of is the fact that the building was in a faded spray paint mural. A faded Aurora logo was painted on the building along with two other logos that said "Lindberg" and "Hawk". Model businesses are truly a rough business to be in. AMT, probably back in the early 1970s made FritoLay trucks for the Fritos Guys We'd Kill For More campaign. The trucks looked almost identical to AMT's CocaCola can trucks. I saw a video from a television news company in the Alabama are recently about a decal company that is in the process of releasing model wrapper stickers for the old-scale AMT CocaCola trailers. These stickers make the kits look more realistic than if people were to buy that kit with the original sticker sheet that comes with it. One of the problems that I have with the CocaCola truck is the fact that the original build-up of a model that I bought that came with fine point CocaCola bottle caps to push inside the trailer is that the decal that I did buy for the truck wound up with cuts on the decal so the best advice that I can give anyone who buys the CocaCola trailer is that the kit comes with cardboard layout material that should be stained with brown paint and not gray paint. Grey paint looks OK but a CocaCola kit needs to have a more conservative material inserted into the truck's open slots. One model company put out genuine 1970's CocaCola truck can decals just for this kit. Most models built back in the day come with white tires known as polymer (whitewalls). If you keep your model collection in a relatively safe environment away from dust, dirt and water, these tires do not dry out.
